CONJUGATES: carols (n. pl.) | carols (v. 3rd sg.) | caroling/carolling (v. pres. part.) | caroled/carolled (v. past/p.p.)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French carole ('a kind of dance'), from Vulgar Latin *caraula, from Latin choraula ('flute player'), from Ancient Greek χοραύλης (khoraúlēs, 'flute player accompanying a chorus')
SINCE: Late 13th century (as a type of dance and song); 15th century (specifically a Christmas song)

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A joyful religious song or hymn, especially one celebrating Christmas.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （尤指圣诞节时的）颂歌，赞美诗
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The children sang Christmas carols around the decorated tree.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 孩子们围着装饰好的圣诞树唱颂歌。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word or phrase that describes an action, condition, or experience.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To sing carols, especially in a joyful or festive manner.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （尤指在圣诞节时）唱颂歌；欢唱
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: They went from house to house caroling for their neighbors.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他们挨家挨户地为邻居唱颂歌。

REGISTER: Common usage, often associated with holiday seasons.
